Thank you for joining this #FridayFocus on the President’s budget and how Congress starts its appropriations process.  Stay tuned for future updates as we continue crafting legislation that will fund the government in fiscal year 2020.
Congress holds the power of the purse and it is important that we craft a thoughtful budget that takes into account the needs of Americans – not just the desires of the President.
As we continue on the appropriations process I’ll be sharing more info about the programs I support and why.

To name just a few – I’m supporting funding for medical research, affordable housing programs, Community 
Development Block Grants, community health centers, law enforcement grants, and gun violence prevention measures.
I’ve signed letters supporting numerous programs that make a real difference in communities across the country.

Deadlines are set for when these letters of support are then sent to one of the 12 subcommittees with specific jurisdiction over these programs, where they are reviewed by appropriators and used to create a final budget resolution.
These letters outline recommended funding levels for programs important to our constituents.

This is where the appropriations process comes in.  Congress appropriates funding to different departments and each member can circulate and sign letters of support for programs, agencies, or priorities.
As I mentioned, along with oversight we also play a role in the crafting of a budget resolution and the eventual bills that set funding levels for the next fiscal year.

It is important that we have the opportunity to hear from these officials because, although the Executive Branch does not have the power of the purse, they are in charge of overseeing the execution of the programs that Congress funds and it is important to get their insight.

As a newly appointed member of the @budgetdems it is now my responsibility to question officials on funding levels and the Committee has had three administration members come in to discuss the sharp cuts to numerous non-defense programs.
The Committee will convene regularly to receive updates on the direction of our government’s spending and how our annual budget can best reflect the priorities of our nation.
One of the Committee’s main responsibilities is to carry out oversight on budget proposals that are presented to Congress.

The Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 created the Budget Committee to allow Congress to develop a self-governing group of members to analyze the President’s budget proposal and unite it with congressional plans.

It’s important to note, though, that these are just suggestions. The budget is what the president *wants* programs/agencies/departments to be funded at – Congress reviews the wish list and changes it to reflect *its* own priorities.

So, for example, if a president thinks affordable housing or the Special Olympics are good, positive things that the government should get behind, his budget proposal will include funding for the departments that oversee those programs.

So, each year the President sends his proposed budget – what he would ideally like Congress to do – for members of Congress to review.   A budget is like a statement of principles – a president’s budget will mirror a president's values.

Everything from the Department of Defense to the National Institutes of Health fall under the Executive Branch and each year funding levels must be set. However, the President does not have the power of the purse – the Constitution explicitly gives that authority to Congress.

The President’s budget is a (very large) document outlining the Administration’s policy priorities and how they ought to be funded. The document itself is very large because the Executive Branch oversees massive government agencies.
Overall, the federal budget process is straightforward: in the spring, the president proposes a budget, Congress reviews that budget, and then Congress tries to agree on a final budget resolution.

On March 11, 2019, the President released his budget proposal for the next fiscal year.  This budget goes to Congress and is available to the public as a statement of the administration’s priorities.  For today’s #FridayFocus let’s look at how the budget process actually works.

As a member of the House T&I Committee and Budget Committee, I’ll work to get our States the money they need. Politics shouldn’t get in the way of keeping commuters safe and keeping our economy strong. No matter your party, infrastructure failures are bad for everyone.

Thanks for joining us today as we looked at the projects in need of funding along the Corridor. Follow our boss as we fight to help the 8th District and the nation better. We’ll keep looking at other infra priorities in the region. Sires staff signing off!

Today’s tour from DC to NYC highlighted once again that rail infrastructure is key to transporting people and goods. It is only a piece of the puzzle that keeps our nation’s transportation systems running smoothly but if one piece is missing, the whole thing suffers.
Today was just a brief overview of the NEC’s infrastructure struggle. Old bridges and tunnels don’t get fixed by themselves, and states need federal help to finance these upgrades.

Specifically, if one of the 2 tunnels fail, rail capacity on this route between NYC and NJ would drop by 75%. That would cripple the economy, the housing market, and job prospects in the region. This doomsday scenario would take years, if not decades, to recover from.

The Gateway Project would repair New Jersey and New York’s share of this infra. It would take some time and be expensive, but it’s worth it. If this any part of this infrastructure fails, in Jersey or in Maryland or anywhere else along the Corridor, it’d be bad for all of us.
Here’s a close up look at the state of these 100+ year old tunnels. pic.twitter.com/0lNGFttmiw
Again, though, decades of nonstop use will degrade anything, and Superstorm Sandy made things worse. I’m 2012, the storm flooded these tunnels, and the saltwater did some terrible damage.

So you have an idea of how important it is — the tunnel hosts 450 trains each day, carrying about 200k commuters between Newark and Manhattan. Basically, this is the busiest rail corridor in the Western Hemisphere.

We all know about the Hudson tunnel and it’s challenges. It’s bad enough that this is another piece of infrastructure that’s over a century old, but this also happens to be *the* linchpin of the NE Corridor.

The Portal Bridge is over a century old and is used by over 400 trains each day. It is a major source of delays and there are frequent electrical and mechanical issues. A clear sign that repair/replacement is long overdue. pic.twitter.com/hBpaafxhkD
The Gateway Project is the plan to address a lot of these problems and is broken into a series of smaller goals including work on the Portal North Bridge and the Hudson Tunnels.
Unfortunately, as we’ve shown throughout the morning, a lot of the infrastructure supporting the movement of millions is in desperate need of repair and replacement.

Staffers here - we’re arriving in the 8th District! Not only is this area home to some of the best people we have the pleasure of working for - Rep. Sires’ constituents - it is also home to one of the biggest transportation hubs in the nation. pic.twitter.com/xtmBLMsaBV
I’m also joining other colleagues’ appropriations efforts to raise funding for transpo infrastructure grants. This is a national necessity.

I’m asking for $500m above the President’s request and for fair distribution of grant funding for public transpo projects. If that sounds like a lot, that’s because it is. But we can’t keep limping along with patchwork bills and erratic funding levels.

And during the yearly appropriations process, I get involved in requests for federal infrastructure program funding. This year, I’m leading a letter to increase funding for BUILD grants, which are available for large infra projects that States can’t handle on their own.
Here’s the bill:  https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/house-bill/543?q=%7B%22search%22%3A%5B%22Hr543%22%5D%7D&s=1&r=1 … pic.twitter.com/mFewMH0g7T

During the regular legislative season, I propose & debate transpo infra bills. For example, the House unanimously passed one of my rail safety oversight bills in Feb. It’s a step in the right direction and shows that there’s strong bipartisan support for rail safety legislation
I’m a member of @TransportDems, which means I’m involved in most transportation infrastructure debates in Congress. I take that responsibility seriously.

My staffers have entered the great state of New Jersey! As a member of the @TransportDems and the only NJ member on @HouseBudgetDems part of my responsibilities are carrying out oversight on the budget and pushing for federal funding for important infrastructure projects. pic.twitter.com/s53ZNfGCeZ

The sad thing is that these old bridges and tunnels aren’t an exception. They’re *all around the country*. New Jersey is home to two very important, and very old, pieces transit infrastructure that are in serious need of repair.

Here’s the Susquehanna River bridge in Maryland, another piece of over 100 year old infrastructure (it opened in 1906). Just to give you an idea of how old this bridge is, it’s about as old as human flight (1903). pic.twitter.com/DgIZhu4Q0C
Here’s a look at the tunnel, which is broken into 3 sections and is suffering from constant water leaks and maintenance challenges. pic.twitter.com/VGVIyLWPYP

First example: the Baltimore & Potomac tunnel. It’s literally 19th century infrastructure (built in 1873) and one of the linchpins of the NE Corridor. 1 of every 4 Amtrak trains make their way through it.
It’s old infrastructure, though. Decades of nonstop use will degrade anything — and if one section of the track goes down, it affects every rider from Washington, DC to Boston.
The Northeast Corridor hosts millions of riders every year in our country’s economic powerhouse region. That’s why it’s so important for Congress to invest in transportation infrastructure funding.
Sires staff here - we’ve departed DC and are en route to the 8th District and NYC. Here is a view of the tracks that millions of commuters and Amtrak riders use every year. pic.twitter.com/JXqNAkHjdO
We desperately need federal funding to repair our crumbling infrastructure but the President’s budget proposal cuts key programs that are used to shore up our rail lines, bridges and tunnels.

Today, I sent members of my staff to join other NJ and NY offices on an infrastructure tour of parts of the Northeast Corridor. Follow along as they look at our nation’s infrastructure needs - including the Gateway Project.

I also asked if the President had consulted any mayors when he decided to eliminate the Community Development Block Grant program.  I know firsthand how useful CDBG funding can be and I think it is ridiculous that the President tries again and again to scrap the program.
